study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the plaque-inhibiting effects of oil pulling therapy using coconut oil versus sesame oil in a 4-day plaque regrowth model.
results_summary: Coconut oil and sesame oil showed similar effectiveness in inhibiting plaque regrowth and tooth staining, with no significant differences in gingival index or bleeding on probing. Both oils were equally effective for oil pulling therapy.
population_specificity: 24 participants in a clinical observer-masked, randomized, crossover study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (oil pulling therapy used as mouthrinse).
study_duration: 4 days per intervention, with a 14-day washout period between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE) in the changes caused by EGCG and ketone bodies (from coconut oil) on body fat and inflammation in MS patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in IL-6 and fat percentage, along with increases in BuChE, βHB, PON1, albumin, and functional capacity. The control group only exhibited a decrease in IL-6.
population_specificity: 51 MS patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of VCO gel on periodontal tissue regeneration by measuring the expression of TNF-α and TGF-β1 in periodontitis-induced rats.
results_summary: VCO gel significantly increased TNF-α and TGF-β1 expression, though less than the positive and negative control groups, suggesting it can influence periodontal tissue regeneration.
population_specificity: 30 male periodontitis-induced Wistar rats.
effective_dosage: Not specified (VCO mixed with NaCMC for gel viscosity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective and antioxidant effects of Coconut Oil in carbon tetrachloride-intoxicated rabbits.
results_summary: Coconut Oil (200 mL/kg) significantly reduced elevated liver enzyme levels (ALT, AST, ALP) and showed similar hepatoprotective effects to silymarine. It also increased WBC count but did not significantly affect other hematological parameters.
population_specificity: Carbon tetrachloride-intoxicated rabbits (n=40, divided into five groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how incorporating herbal extracts into coconut oil affects its thermal diffusivity, validating traditional Ayurvedic knowledge about body temperature acclimatization.
results_summary: The study found that adding black pepper to coconut oil lowered thermal diffusivity (heat-trapping effect), while aloe vera, hibiscus bud, and Ocimum sanctum increased it (cooling effect), supporting traditional claims about thermal properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on oil samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified (herbal extract compositions not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (thermal diffusivity measurements likely instantaneous).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate patterns, reasons, and beliefs related to coconut oil consumption and its perceived health benefits in a population in southern Brazil.
results_summary: Most coconut oil consumers (82.5%) considered it healthy, but 81.2% reported no health improvements. After exposure to scientific evidence contradicting its benefits, 73.5% of consumers maintained their belief in its healthiness. Non-consumers cited cost (47.6%) and perceived unhealthiness (11.6%) as reasons for avoiding it.
population_specificity: Online survey respondents from southern Brazil (n=3160).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of coconut oil combined with EGCG on cortisol activity, fat loss, and depression in MS patients.
results_summary: The study found that coconut oil combined with EGCG significantly increased albumin levels, reduced depression, and decreased abdominal fat in MS patients, though cortisol levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 51 MS patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of virgin coconut oil (VCO) on biochemical markers and recovery in suspect and probable COVID-19 cases.
results_summary: Participants receiving VCO showed a significant decline in C-reactive protein levels, with normalization by day 14, suggesting faster recovery from COVID-19 compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 63 adults in isolation facilities in Santa Rosa City, Laguna, Philippines, classified as suspect or probable COVID-19 cases.
effective_dosage: Predefined dosage of VCO mixed with standardized meals (exact amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of topical coconut oil application on the scalp microbiome and its correlation with scalp health in individuals with and without dandruff.
results_summary: Coconut oil treatment increased the abundance of beneficial microbes (Cutibacterium acnes and Malassezia globosa) and healthy scalp-related bacterial pathways while reducing fungal pathogenesis pathways, correlating with improved scalp health.
population_specificity: 140 Indian women (70 healthy, 70 with dandruff).
study_duration: 12 weeks of treatment, 4 weeks of relapse phase

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and summarize high-quality evidence on the health-related benefits of coconut oil from systematic reviews and meta-analyses of interventional studies.
results_summary: Coconut oil significantly increased serum total cholesterol, LDL, and HDL levels compared to poly- and mono-unsaturated oils. Limited evidence suggested benefits for atopic dermatitis and dental caries prevention, but conclusions were constrained by the small number of studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from interventional studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effect of a novel formulation (Phoscoliv) combining virgin coconut oil and phosphatidylcholine in preventing and treating liver damage.
results_summary: Phoscoliv significantly boosted antioxidant status, inhibited ROS generation, blocked lipid peroxidation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, maintaining normal liver architecture. The study concluded that Phoscoliv is a potent and safe hepatoprotective medicine.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Virgin Coconut Oil (VCO) as a natural prophylactic agent to counteract skin damage caused by frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers (ABHS).
results_summary: The study found that overnight VCO application helped protect skin from ABHS-induced damage, with a 25% increase in perceived moisture content and resistance to lipid and protein extraction. Instrumental studies confirmed these protective effects.
population_specificity: 60 volunteers in an in-home usage study and 12 subjects (aged 25-60) in a non-invasive instrumental study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of virgin coconut oil (VCO) consumption on metabolic syndrome (MetS) components and asymmetric dimethylarginine (ADMA) in adults with MetS.
results_summary: VCO consumption significantly reduced triglyceride (TG), very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL), and fasting blood sugar (FBS) levels while increasing HDL-C, LDL-C, total cholesterol (TC), and ADMA. No significant changes were observed in blood pressure, waist circumference, or the LDL-C/HDL-C ratio.
population_specificity: Adults aged 20-50 years with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
effective_dosage: 30 ml of VCO per day, substituted for the same amount of fat in their usual diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of coconut oil supplementation on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, ruminal fermentation, and blood metabolites in Hainan Black goat kids.
results_summary: Coconut oil supplementation improved growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and reduced estimated methane emissions, with 6 g/day being optimal. Higher doses (8 g/day) suppressed growth, feed conversion, and rumen microbial activity.
population_specificity: Hainan Black goat kids (10 days of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of coconut oil supplementation on glucose metabolism, particularly in a diabetic patient on insulin, and review existing literature on its metabolic impacts.
results_summary: The case report documented recurrent hypoglycemia in a diabetic patient after coconut oil supplementation, suggesting a potential favorable effect on glycemic control. However, the literature review indicated inconsistent results, likely due to variations in coconut oil types and limited trials.
population_specificity: A 66-year-old man with type 2 diabetes managed with insulin.
interactions: Reduction in insulin therapy required due to hypoglycemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize a coconut oil and simvastatin nanoemulsion for burn wound healing, assessing its anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and wound-closure effects.
results_summary: The coconut oil-simvastatin nanoemulsion significantly reduced burn wound diameter (5.3-fold decrease), interleukin-6 levels (4.25-fold decrease), and enhanced antimicrobial activity (6-fold increase in inhibition zone against Staphylococcus aureus).
population_specificity: Experimental animals (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of oil pulling with coconut oil on improving oral health and dental hygiene.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in salivary bacterial colony count and plaque index score, with one study showing a significant difference in staining compared to Chlorhexidine. However, data was insufficient for conclusive findings, and the quality of studies was mixed with a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: 182 participants across four randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a shampoo containing 1% fractionated coconut oil in treating head lice infestations.
results_summary: The shampoo eliminated lice in only 7/31 participants after the first application and 12/31 by the end of the study, failing to kill all life stages of lice. The results suggest minimal intrinsic activity of coconut oil against head lice.
population_specificity: 31 people with head lice infestations.
effective_dosage: Shampoo containing 1% fractionated coconut oil, applied on day 0 and day 8.
study_duration: 16 days (assessments on day 1, day 8, and day 16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and effectiveness of coconut oil as a therapy for radiation-induced xerostomia in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: Coconut oil use was feasible and safe, with no adverse events reported. However, there was no statistically significant improvement in xerostomia-related quality of life scores, though some patients continued use beyond the advised period.
population_specificity: 30 patients with xerostomia following radiation therapy for head and neck cancer.
effective_dosage: Average of 5 mL per use, 3 times daily.
study_duration: 2-week initial period, with some patients continuing up to 71 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of coconut oil pulling as an adjuvant in reducing plaque formation and treating plaque-induced gingivitis.
results_summary: The study found that coconut oil pulling significantly reduced plaque index (PI) and bleeding index (BI) more than the control group, with no reported significant side effects. The improvements were clinically relevant, though further research is needed for broader validation.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-35 with plaque-induced gingivitis.
effective_dosage: Daily application as a mouthwash (specific volume not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether virgin coconut oil could mitigate the neurotoxic effects of l-dopa in rats.
results_summary: Virgin coconut oil co-treatment significantly reduced l-dopa-induced neurotoxicity, oxidative stress, and neurodegeneration while improving neurotransmitter balance and behavioral abnormalities.
population_specificity: Adult rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of coconut oil ingestion on the gastrointestinal microbiomes of pigs, focusing on changes in bacterial communities.
results_summary: Coconut oil supplementation significantly altered the bacterial community composition, increasing beneficial bacteria like Lactobacillus and decreasing others like Corynebacterium, though it did not affect overall bacterial diversity. The changes were statistically significant (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: Pigs (19 total, divided into two groups: 9 on a normal diet and 10 on a coconut oil-supplemented diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of coconut oil on body composition, lipid profile, and glycemia in men with obesity.
results_summary: Coconut oil increased HDL cholesterol and decreased the TC/HDL cholesterol ratio compared to soybean oil, but no significant changes were observed in anthropometric variables.
population_specificity: 29 adult men affected by obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether virgin coconut oil (VCO) could prevent diclofenac-induced oxidative nephrotoxicity in rats by leveraging its antioxidant properties.
results_summary: VCO supplementation attenuated renal damage caused by diclofenac, restored antioxidant enzyme activities, and reduced TNF-α levels in the kidneys. The study found statistically significant improvements in oxidative stress markers and histopathological outcomes.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: 5 or 10 ml/kg body weight, orally administered
study_duration: 21 days of VCO supplementation prior to diclofenac administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of thymoquinone-loaded coconut oil nanostructured lipid carriers (NLC) in treating ethanol-induced gastric ulcers.
results_summary: The TQ-loaded coconut oil NLC showed significant gastroprotective effects, with 78.95% inhibition of ulcerative index compared to 30.87% for TQ suspension alone. The formulation demonstrated a biphasic drug release pattern and high entrapment efficiency (85.63%).
population_specificity: Alcohol-induced ulcer model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coconut oil could maintain glucose homeostasis, growth performance, and immune function in nursery and grower pigs as effectively as antibiotics.
results_summary: Coconut oil maintained feed intake, weight gain, and immune function similarly to antibiotics but reduced serum insulin levels. It neither harmed nor benefited growth performance or immune function compared to antibiotic-free diets.
population_specificity: Nursery and grower pigs (weaning to 71 days of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective antioxidant effects of virgin coconut oil (VCO) on urea and creatinine levels following maximal physical activity in rats.
results_summary: The study found that VCO was effective in preventing oxidative stress after maximal physical activity, as indicated by measured levels of urea, creatinine, malondialdehyde, and glutathione peroxidase. The results suggest VCO may mitigate exercise-induced oxidative damage.
population_specificity: 24 healthy male rats divided into four groups.
effective_dosage: 1 mL/200 gBW, 2 mL/200 gBW, and 4 mL/200 gBW per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether formulating methotrexate (MTX) in a coconut oil nanoemulsion (MTX-NE COCO) could enhance its antineoplastic efficacy while reducing oxidative stress-related toxicity in the brain and lungs.
results_summary: MTX-NE COCO showed a lower IC50 (18 µM) compared to free MTX (32 µM), indicating improved efficacy. In vivo, it increased antioxidant enzyme activity and reduced malondialdehyde levels in brain and lung tissues compared to free MTX.
population_specificity: A549 non-small cell lung cancer cells and mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 values provided: 18 µM for MTX-NE COCO, 32 µM for free MTX).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of virgin coconut oil (VCO) and hydrolyzed virgin coconut oil (HVCO) on protein expression (MMP-9, PDGF-BB, and TGF-β1) in NIH 3T3 cells to assess their role in wound healing.
results_summary: Both VCO and HVCO significantly increased the expression of MMP-9, PDGF-BB, and TGF-β1 in NIH 3T3 cells, with HVCO showing a stronger effect than VCO, suggesting their potential activity in wound healing.
population_specificity: NIH 3T3 cells (a mouse fibroblast cell line) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Not specified (cells were treated with VCO and HVCO, but exact concentrations are not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the ketogenic effect of coconut oil (Coc) and caprylic acid (C8), with and without glucose intake, compared to sunflower oil (Suf).
results_summary: C8 had a higher ketogenic effect than Coc, which was not significantly different from Suf or C8 with glucose. A 16-hour non-carbohydrate window contributed to mild ketosis while blood glucose remained stable.
population_specificity: 15 healthy volunteers aged 65-73, 53% women.
effective_dosage: 30 g of coconut oil (Coc), 20 g of caprylic acid (C8) + 10 g sunflower oil (Suf), and combinations with 50 g glucose.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with measurements over 4 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of virgin coconut oil (VCO) and tocotrienol-rich fraction (TRF) could protect against bone loss induced by ovariectomy and high-fat diet in rats.
results_summary: The combination of VCO and TRF significantly reduced bone resorption markers and improved bone formation parameters compared to other groups, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for osteoporosis. No significant differences in osteocalcin levels were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Sprague-Dawley rats fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: VCO at 4.29 ml/kg and TRF at 30 mg/kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of coconut oil on circulating fatty acid concentrations and examine associations between changes in plasma fatty acids and metabolic markers.
results_summary: Coconut oil significantly increased lauric acid (C12:0) and myristic acid (C14:0) concentrations compared to olive oil and butter, but changes in fatty acids mostly showed no significant associations with metabolic markers.
population_specificity: 96 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical emollient oil application reduces infection risk in preterm infants.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that preterm infants receiving emollient oil massages had a 21% reduced risk of infection (RR=0.79, 95% CI 0.64–0.97). The study concluded that topical emollient oil is likely effective in preventing infections, though further research is needed.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a glycerin-C. nucifera (coconut oil) cream versus glycerin-only cream for the secondary prevention of occupational hand dermatitis (OHD) among batik workers.
results_summary: Both the glycerin-C. nucifera and glycerin-only creams were equally effective, showing a 20% decrease in HECSI and TEWL, and a 20% increase in skin capacitance, indicating clinical improvement in OHD.
population_specificity: Batik dyeing and/or rinsing workers with mild to moderate occupational hand dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Multiple after-work applications of moisturizer (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of EGCG, particularly when combined with coconut oil, in improving metabolic health markers, functional abilities, and quality of life in MS patients.
results_summary: EGCG supplementation, especially with coconut oil, improved metabolic health markers, functional abilities (e.g., gait speed, balance), and quality of life (e.g., reduced depression scores), but did not significantly impact primary disease progression markers like EDSS scores or MRI lesions.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: 600 mg to 1200 mg of EGCG daily (coconut oil dosage not specified).
study_duration: Most studies had a 4-month follow-up period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of coconut oil and palm olein oil on serum lipoprotein lipids and biochemical parameters in healthy adults.
results_summary: Coconut oil consumption increased LDL-C by 5.6% and TC by 4.0%, indicating less favorable changes in lipid-related CVD risk factors compared to palm olein oil. The study concluded that palm olein oil had more beneficial effects on lipid profiles.
population_specificity: 40 healthy adults (37 completed the study).
study_duration: 8 weeks per feeding period with a 16-week washout in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of gastric lavage with oil-based solutions (including paraffin oil) versus non-oil-based methods in treating acute aluminum phosphide poisoning.
results_summary: Paraffin oil was significantly associated with reduced mortality risk (RR = 0.59) in patients with acute aluminum phosphide poisoning, but the abstract does not specifically mention Coconut Oil.
population_specificity: Patients presenting with acute aluminum phosphide poisoning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of topical emollient oil application, including coconut oil, on weight gain in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that preterm infants who received massages with coconut oil exhibited greater mean differences in weight gain, with a pooled difference of 52.15 grams. Adverse events were minimal, with only two studies reporting occurrences of rash and accidental slippage.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates (1454 participants across 18 studies).
effective_dosage: Massages three times daily (specific oil volume not specified).
study_duration: Duration of therapy varied by study (not explicitly stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antioxidant properties and other beneficial health effects of virgin coconut oil (VCO), including its potential in preventing and treating oxidative stress-induced neurological disorders and other health conditions.
results_summary: The study found that VCO exhibits anticancer, antimicrobial, analgesic, antipyretic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties, primarily due to its lauric acid, phenolic compounds, and medium-chain fatty acids. It is also beneficial for cardiovascular, respiratory, dermatological, reproductive, and bone health, and is safe for dietary supplementation across all age groups.
population_specificity: All age groups (general population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of natural mouthwashes, including coconut oil, for oral health.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that the clinical effectiveness of coconut oil as a mouthwash is still under debate, with no strong evidence supporting its efficacy for plaque or gingivitis reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (general oral health context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical coconut oil improves skin integrity and reduces late-onset sepsis (LOS) in preterm infants, while also examining its effects on early-life skin-microbiome succession.
results_summary: The study found that topical coconut oil improved preterm-infant skin integrity and may reduce LOS. Microbiome diversity was highest on day 1 after birth, with a subsequent decline and emergence of specific microbial patterns.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born before 30 weeks of gestation.
study_duration: Samples were collected on days 1, 7, 14, and 21, suggesting at least a 21-day intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ketogenic therapies, including coconut oil supplementation, in improving cognitive and motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: Coconut oil was used as part of a Mediterranean diet supplementation and showed cognitive improvements, though results were variable and adherence was problematic. MCT supplements, including coconut oil, demonstrated cognitive benefits after 6 months of use.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the chemical composition and health-promoting benefits of 39 kinds of vegetable oils, including Coconut Oil.
results_summary: The abstract does not specify findings related to Coconut Oil, only that it was among the 39 vegetable oils reviewed for health benefits and chemical composition.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the effects of fermented or non-fermented aronia pulp with placebo in subjects with type 2 diabetes mellitus, using snack bars containing coconut oil as part of the formulation.
results_summary: The study did not specifically evaluate the effects of coconut oil; it focused on aronia extracts. Coconut oil was used as an ingredient in the snack bars but its individual impact was not assessed.
population_specificity: Subjects with type 2 diabetes mellitus (23 completed the trial out of 36 randomized participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified for coconut oil (snack bars contained 63% raisins and coconut oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review nutritional and epidemiological aspects of coconut oil, its effects on metabolic and cardiovascular health, and explore reasons for its high consumption despite recent data.
results_summary: The study found that coconut oil does not provide cardiometabolic benefits or improvements in anthropometric, lipid, glycemic, and subclinical inflammation parameters. Its popularity persists due to misinformation and beliefs among health professionals.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of RCTs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of medium-chain fatty acid (MCFA) supplements, such as those found in coconut oil, on circulating ketone bodies and cognition in individuals with subjective cognitive decline, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: MCFA supplementation significantly increased blood ketone body levels, but cognitive outcomes varied, with some studies showing improvement, others no improvement, and some improvement only in APOE ε4 noncarriers. Increased brain energy metabolism and regional cerebral blood flow were also noted in specific subgroups.
population_specificity: Individuals with subjective cognitive decline, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of capric acid (a component of coconut oil) as an alternative energy source for the brain and its efficacy in ameliorating neurological diseases.
results_summary: Capric acid demonstrated potential benefits in neurological conditions like epilepsy, affective disorders, and Alzheimer's disease by targeting AMPA receptors, PPAR-γ, and inflammatory pathways, but further clinical studies are needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (pre-clinical and clinical studies referenced generally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether coconut oil can improve hair growth, hair quality, and treat hair infestation clinically.
results_summary: Coconut oil was shown to treat brittle hair and hair infestation effectively, but evidence for its impact on hair growth was limited. The study found weaker evidence for castor oil and no strong evidence for argan oil in improving hair-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with hair and scalp conditions, particularly those with cultural practices involving hair oils (e.g., Indian and African heritage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of coconut oil, delivered via microneedling, on gingival inflammation and plaque accumulation in patients with gingivitis.
results_summary: Coconut oil combined with microneedling (Group A) showed highly significant reductions in gingival indices, comparable to sesame oil (Group B), while mechanical treatment alone (Group C) had less notable effects. No significant difference in plaque reduction was observed across all groups.
population_specificity: 24 patients with clinically diagnosed plaque-induced gingivitis from Vision Dental Hospital, Riyadh, KSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation enhances gut microbial production of medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs), such as those found in coconut oil, and increases circulating MCFA levels.
results_summary: Personalized magnesium supplementation significantly increased plasma levels of MCFAs (C7:0 and C8:0) and reduced sucrose levels, with changes linked to gut microbial activity. The effects remained significant after adjustments and mediation analysis suggested MCFAs partially mediated the impact on ketone bodies.
population_specificity: 240 participants in the Personalized Prevention of Colorectal Cancer Trial (PPCCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of coconut oil-based interventions (a neem seed and coconut oils-based mixture for treatment and a coconut oil-based lotion for prevention) in managing tungiasis.
results_summary: The coconut oil-based lotion for prevention and dimeticones for treatment showed the most promise among the interventions studied. However, most RCTs included had low methodological quality.
population_specificity: Individuals in resource-limited communities affected by tungiasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the chemical properties, traditional uses, benefits, and possible adverse effects of plant oils, including coconut oil, for skin and scalp care in Nigeria and Africa.
results_summary: Coconut oil and other plant oils were found to promote healthy skin barrier function, wound healing, and have anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial effects, though adverse effects may occur due to processing and storage hygiene.
population_specificity: Traditional healers, alternative health practitioners, and general users in Nigeria and other African countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of topical coconut oil on invasive infection and mortality in preterm infants compared to other emollients.
results_summary: One trial involving 64 preterm infants found no episodes of invasive infection or death in either the coconut oil or mineral oil group, but the evidence was of very low certainty. The abstract does not provide conclusive efficacy data for coconut oil.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with birth weight 1500 g to 2000 g in India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of coconut oil on body weight reduction compared to other oils and fats.
results_summary: Coconut oil showed a small but statistically significant reduction in body weight, BMI, and fat mass percentage, but no significant effect on waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, or fat mass.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
study_duration: Varied from four weeks to two years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coconut oil (EVCO), alone or combined with aerobic exercise, could lower blood pressure in stage 1 hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found no antihypertensive effect from coconut oil, either alone or combined with exercise, and no impact on blood pressure variability or oxidative stress. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 45 hypertensive volunteers of both genders with stage 1 hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of coconut oil, compared to other vegetable oils, on intestinal microbiota composition, permeability, LPS concentrations, and fecal short-chain fatty acids in overweight women.
results_summary: Coconut oil intake increased intestinal permeability (both paracellular and transcellular) but did not affect bacterial diversity, LPS concentrations, or metabolic endotoxemia. The effects on microbiota and permeability were modest.
population_specificity: Overweight women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of coconut oil (as a source of ketone bodies) combined with EGCG on cardiac risk and anthropometric variables in MS patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant increases in beneficial biomarkers (BHB, PON1, albumin), reduced cardiac risk (lower WHR), increased muscle percentage, and decreased WHtR and fat mass, while the control group did not exhibit these changes.
population_specificity: 51 patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of coconut oil and EGCG on IL-6 levels, anxiety, and functional disability in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The intervention group (coconut oil + EGCG) showed decreased state anxiety and improved functional capacity, while IL-6 levels decreased in both groups, possibly due to the Mediterranean diet's antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: 51 patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic applications of nutritional ketosis, including the use of fractionated coconut oil, in neurodegenerative and neuroprogressive disorders by examining its effects on neuronal function and astrocyte interactions.
results_summary: The study suggests that nutritional ketosis, including the use of fractionated coconut oil, may mitigate detrimental effects in neurodegenerative disorders by improving astrocytic function, reducing oxidative stress, and enhancing neuronal fuel supply under glucose restriction. These mechanisms could potentially benefit conditions like mild cognitive impairment, Parkinson's disease, and schizophrenia.
population_specificity: Individuals with neurodegenerative and neuroprogressive disorders (e.g., epilepsy, mild cognitive impairment, Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, autistic spectrum disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence surrounding coconut oil consumption and its impact on cardiovascular health, particularly its effects on lipid profiles.
results_summary: Coconut oil significantly increased HDL-C compared to both plant and animal oils, raised LDL-C compared to plant oils, and lowered LDL-C compared to animal oils. No significant effects on triglycerides were observed, with virgin coconut oil showing better lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of coconut oil intake on cardiometabolic health, including lipid profiles and potential non-lipid effects like weight loss.
results_summary: Coconut oil intake increased LDL-C, HDL-C, and total cholesterol compared to other vegetable oils but failed to demonstrate efficacy as a weight loss strategy. Long-term clinical trials are needed to confirm the clinical relevance of HDL-C increases.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of coconut oil consumption on blood lipids and other cardiovascular risk factors compared with other cooking oils using clinical trial data.
results_summary: Coconut oil significantly increased LDL-cholesterol compared to nontropical vegetable oils but did not show significant effects on other cardiovascular risk factors like body weight, body fat, or inflammation markers. The study concluded that coconut oil's LDL-raising effect should inform dietary choices.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of clinical trials).
study_duration: At least 2 weeks (duration varied across included trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review randomized trials assessing the effects of topical coconut oil on preterm infants, focusing on its emollient and anti-infective properties.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significantly lower incidence of hospital-acquired bloodstream infections (HABSI) in the coconut oil group compared to controls, with a relative risk of 0.35. The majority of trials included relatively mature preterm infants, and outcomes varied among studies.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (gestation > 32 weeks, birth weight > 1200 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of palm olein (a saturated fatty acid-rich oil) with other oils, including coconut oil, on serum lipid markers of cardiovascular disease risk in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in lipoprotein biomarkers between palm olein and other dietary oils, including coconut oil. Palm olein had effects comparable to unsaturated oils but differed from saturated fatty acid-rich oils in serum lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of coconut oil consumption on anthropometric, biochemical, and inflammatory markers compared to peanut oil in healthy men.
results_summary: Coconut oil consumption increased fat-free mass, HDL-cholesterol, and insulin sensitivity while reducing inflammatory markers linked to cardiovascular disease. No such benefits were observed with peanut oil.
population_specificity: Nine healthy male volunteers with BMI ≤25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of short, medium, and long-chain saturated fatty acids (SFA) on postprandial blood lipids, specifically evaluating coconut oil's impact relative to butter and lard.
results_summary: Coconut oil (CB) resulted in significantly lower postprandial triglyceride (TG) responses compared to butter (BB) and lard (LB), but increased LDL-C levels relative to butter. No differences were observed in total cholesterol (TC) or HDL-C responses.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 40 g of coconut oil (CB) in test biscuits
study_duration: Single meal intervention with blood sampling up to 6 hours postprandially

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of herbal medicinal products, including a topical spray containing coconut oil, for neuropathic pain relief.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief between the nutmeg spray (containing coconut oil) and placebo, with very low-quality evidence. Adverse events and withdrawal rates were similar between treatment and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Adults (18+) with neuropathic pain conditions lasting at least three months, including diabetic neuropathy and non-diabetic neuropathic pain.
effective_dosage: 125 mL topical spray (containing coconut oil, applied for four weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current literature on the health effects of coconut oil products, focusing on their fatty acid profiles and potential benefits or drawbacks.
results_summary: Coconut oil shows limited but consistent evidence for topical use in atopic dermatitis and dental caries prevention, but lacks support for Alzheimer's disease, bone loss, or glycemic control. Effects on weight loss and cardiovascular disease require further clinical studies.
population_specificity: General human population, with some focus on specific conditions (e.g., atopic dermatitis, dental caries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of coconut oil in treating atopic dermatitis and xerosis, focusing on children, and assess its potential benefits or drawbacks compared to other oils.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that coconut oil's efficacy for atopic dermatitis and xerosis remains inconclusive, with further studies needed for definitive recommendations. Olive oil was noted to potentially worsen these conditions, but coconut oil's effects were not clearly established.
population_specificity: Children with atopic dermatitis and xerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of coconut oil versus corn oil on lipids, glucose homeostasis, and inflammation in adults with elevated cholesterol.
results_summary: Coconut oil consumption led to less favorable lipid profiles compared to corn oil, including increased LDL cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, and total cholesterol, though differences in total-C and LDL cholesterol only approached significance. No significant differences were observed in hs-CRP or glucose metabolism parameters.
population_specificity: Adults (12 men, 13 women) with a mean age of 45.2, BMI of 27.7, fasting LDL cholesterol ≥115 mg/dL and <190 mg/dL, and triglycerides ≤375 mg/dL.
effective_dosage: ~54 g/day (4 tablespoons) incorporated into muffins and rolls.
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention, with a 3-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dietary caprylic acid (found in coconut oil) in modulating ghrelin octanoylation and its potential implications for obesity management.
results_summary: The study suggests that caprylic acid from coconut oil may influence ghrelin octanoylation, potentially affecting appetite regulation and offering a therapeutic strategy against obesity by modulating ghrelin levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (general nutritional context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a coconut oil-enriched Mediterranean diet could improve cognitive functions in Alzheimer's disease patients and whether effects varied by disease stage or sex.
results_summary: The study found improvements in episodic memory, temporal orientation, and semantic memory after coconut oil intervention, with more pronounced effects in women with mild-moderate AD, though benefits were also observed in males and severe cases.
population_specificity: 44 patients with Alzheimer's disease, divided into experimental and control groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of coconut oil supplementation on anthropometric and biochemical parameters in obese women on a hypocaloric diet with lifestyle modifications.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding coconut oil's effects, only mentioning the study's design and participant groups.
population_specificity: Obese women (BMI 30–39.9 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical utility of coconut oil consumption, focusing on its purported benefits and potential cardiovascular risks.
results_summary: The study found that coconut oil increases LDL-C, potentially raising cardiovascular risks, and cautioned against generalizing the benefits of commercial MCT oils to coconut oil. It recommended limiting coconut oil intake to less than 10% of total daily calories.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).
effective_dosage: Not specified (recommended less than 10% of total calorie intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the fatty acid profiles and metabolic effects of new intravenous lipid emulsions (IVLEs), including those containing coconut oil, against traditional soybean oil-based IVLEs.
results_summary: The study found that new IVLEs containing coconut oil, among other oils, provide fewer essential fatty acids than pure soybean oil but may reduce serum triglycerides when combined with fish oil. No direct adverse effects of coconut oil were mentioned.
population_specificity: Patients requiring parenteral nutrition (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and effects of topical coconut oil on skin condition in very preterm infants.
results_summary: Topical coconut oil maintained better skin condition in very preterm infants compared to routine care, with no adverse effects reported. The intervention was feasible and did not affect common neonatal outcomes like sepsis or mortality.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born at less than 30 weeks' gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the popularity and expected therapeutic activity of coconut oil and other natural agents in treating atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The abstract mentions coconut oil as a popular topical agent for atopic dermatitis but does not provide specific efficacy results or adverse effects. A critical review of literature is presented, focusing on potential side effects of other agents like hepatotoxicity with Chinese herbals.
population_specificity: Patients and parents of children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of natural plant-based oils, including coconut oil, in dermatology, particularly for repairing skin-barrier function.
results_summary: The study highlights that coconut oil, among other natural oils, may aid in skin-barrier repair due to its fatty acid composition, though oils with higher linoleic acid to oleic acid ratios are preferred for better barrier repair potential. The method of oil extraction (e.g., cold pressing) also influences efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dermatological application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of natural herbal medicines, including coconut oil, for treating atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: Coconut oil was found to contribute to the down-regulation of AD-related symptoms, including SCORAD index, erythema intensity, and transepidermal water loss, when used alone or with other complementary therapies. The review highlighted its potential in treating mild-to-severe AD across various populations.
population_specificity: Adults, children, infants, and pregnant women with mild-to-severe AD.

study_goal: The researchers were assessing the effects of coconut oil massage as part of a broader treatment for post-burn pruritus, alongside laser therapy and cetirizine.
results_summary: Coconut oil was used as part of the treatment regimen, but the study did not isolate its effects. The primary outcomes focused on laser therapy and cetirizine, with no specific results reported for coconut oil alone.
population_specificity: 49 adult burn patients with post-burn pruritus (mean age 31.53 ± 10.14 years).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with a 12-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary intake of specific fatty acids, including myristic acid found in coconut oil, affects the risk of disease flares in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: High dietary intake of myristic acid (found in coconut oil) was associated with an increased risk of UC flare, while other previously implicated foods showed no such association. The study suggests a potential negative effect of coconut oil in UC patients.
population_specificity: 412 patients with UC in remission during monotherapy with an aminosalicylate.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intake analyzed via food frequency questionnaire).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between virgin coconut oil (VCO) and biochemical measurements linked to cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk.
results_summary: The study found that VCO shows promising effects in improving biochemical derangements associated with CVD, potentially lowering CVD risk, but most evidence comes from animal studies with limited human data.
population_specificity: Primarily animal studies, with very limited human data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cardiovascular health claims of coconut oil by reviewing its effects on cardiovascular risk factors and outcomes in humans.
results_summary: Coconut oil raised total and LDL cholesterol more than unsaturated plant oils but less than butter. Observational evidence suggests traditional coconut consumption does not adversely affect cardiovascular health, but findings may not apply to Western diets. Replacing coconut oil with unsaturated fats may reduce cardiovascular risk factors.
population_specificity: Humans (general population, with some focus on traditional dietary patterns).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of liquid coconut oil and coconut oleogel on blood triglycerides, glucose, insulin, and appetite when consumed with a carbohydrate-rich meal.
results_summary: The study measured postprandial responses (blood glucose, insulin, triglycerides, and appetite) over 6 hours after consuming coconut oil or oleogel with a meal, but specific comparative results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 16 healthy young adult males (age 27 ± 6 years, BMI 21.9 ± 1.7 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 22.25 g coconut oil (CO) or 25 g coconut oleogel (CG, containing 22.25 g coconut oil + 2.75 g ethylcellulose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether topical coconut oil application reduces trans-epidermal water loss (TEWL) and improves skin condition in very low birth weight (VLBW) neonates.
results_summary: Coconut oil application significantly reduced TEWL, improved skin condition, and resulted in lower bacterial growth compared to standard care in VLBW neonates.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) neonates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic role of coconut oil in preventing and managing Alzheimer's disease (AD) by reviewing its mechanistic physiology and benefits.
results_summary: The study found that coconut oil's medium-chain fatty acids (MCFA) may benefit brain function by providing an alternative energy source (ketones) and could help manage obesity, dyslipidaemia, and other risk factors for AD. Phenolic compounds and cytokinins in coconut may also inhibit amyloid-β peptide aggregation, a key step in AD pathogenesis.
population_specificity: General population, with specific focus on individuals at risk for or with memory impairment (e.g., Alzheimer's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of topical coconut oil applications in reducing hospital-acquired bloodstream infections and improving skin condition and weight gain in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that topical coconut oil significantly reduced the risk of bloodstream infections, improved skin condition, and increased weight gain in preterm infants, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Hospital-born preterm infants (gestational age ≥26 weeks and ≤37 weeks) in a tertiary hospital setting in Pakistan.
study_duration: From birth until discharge, continued at home until completion of the 28th day of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the risks and benefits of various natural products, including coconut oil, for late-life mood and cognitive disorders.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about coconut oil's effects, only mentioning it as one of the supplements evaluated.
population_specificity: Geriatric patients and the general adult population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential cardiovascular benefits of virgin coconut oil (VCO) and its mechanisms of action in reducing cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk.
results_summary: The study highlights that VCO, due to its chemical properties and manufacturing process, may offer cardioprotective effects, potentially reducing CVD burden when used alone or combined with exercise. It contrasts VCO with copra-derived coconut oil, suggesting VCO is healthier.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cardiovascular risk population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-protein Malaysian diets prepared with coconut oil (CO) on cell adhesion molecules, lipid inflammatory mediators, and thrombogenicity indices in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in thrombogenicity indices or cell adhesion molecules between diets using coconut oil, palm olein, or olive oil. Coconut oil did not significantly alter plasma leukotriene B4 (LTB4) or prostacyclin (PGF1α) levels compared to the other test fats.
population_specificity: 45 healthy Malaysian men and women.
effective_dosage: Coconut oil was incorporated at two-thirds of 30% fat calories in the high-protein diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of topical virgin coconut oil (VCO) and mineral oil on SCORAD index values, transepidermal water loss (TEWL), and skin capacitance in pediatric patients with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: VCO significantly outperformed mineral oil, reducing SCORAD indices by 68.23% (vs. 38.13%), improving TEWL (7.09 post-treatment vs. 26.68 baseline), and increasing skin capacitance (42.3 vs. 32.0 baseline). Nearly half of VCO-treated patients achieved excellent clinical response.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aromatherapy with coconut oil and Thai massage could improve cellular immunity and reduce symptom severity in colorectal cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that aromatherapy with coconut oil and Thai massage significantly increased lymphocyte counts by 11% and reduced symptom severity for fatigue, pain, and stress compared to standard care.
population_specificity: Sixty-six colorectal cancer patients in Phichit Hospital, Thailand, undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Three massage sessions with ginger and coconut oil over one week (specific oil dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of pregabalin in relieving post-burn itch, with coconut oil massage as a common adjunct therapy across all groups.
results_summary: Coconut oil massage alone was sufficient to decrease mean itch scores in patients with mild itch, but for moderate to severe itch, systemic agents like pregabalin were significantly more effective. The study did not isolate coconut oil's independent efficacy.
population_specificity: 80 adult patients with post-burn itch, divided into four treatment groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of nutritional treatment combined with extra virgin coconut oil consumption on anthropometric parameters and lipid profile in patients with coronary arterial disease (CAD).
results_summary: The study found that nutritional treatment with extra virgin coconut oil reduced waist circumference and increased HDL-C levels in CAD patients, with significant differences observed between the intervention and control groups. Other parameters like body mass and BMI were also maintained or reduced, but no significant changes were noted in other lipid or metabolic markers.
population_specificity: 116 adults (63.2% male, mean age 62.4 ± 7.7 years) with CAD, including 77.6% with prior myocardial infarction, 52.6% with angina, and 100% with hypertension and dyslipidemia.
study_duration: 6 months (3 months of intensive nutritional treatment followed by 3 months of intervention with coconut oil or control diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of coconut oil as a repellent for preventing tungiasis (sand flea disease).
results_summary: The study found that regular application of a coconut oil-based repellent is feasible for preventing tungiasis, a debilitating condition prevalent in resource-poor communities. No effective drug treatment was previously available, making coconut oil a promising preventive measure.
population_specificity: Resource-poor communities in South America and sub-Saharan Africa, particularly children and adults affected by tungiasis.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the management of aluminium phosphide poisoning, including the potential role of coconut oil in treatment.
results_summary: The study found that coconut oil, when used in combination with sodium bicarbonate for gastric lavage or administered orally, may be part of the treatment for aluminium phosphide poisoning. Specific therapy involving coconut oil was noted, but detailed efficacy data were not provided.
population_specificity: Individuals suffering from aluminium phosphide poisoning.

study_goal: The researchers used coconut oil as a placebo to compare against fish oil supplementation, aiming to assess cognitive effects in college-aged individuals.
results_summary: Coconut oil (placebo) showed no significant cognitive benefits compared to fish oil, except for improved performance on the Trail Making Test (TMT), likely due to a learning effect. No adverse effects or significant benefits were reported for coconut oil.
population_specificity: College-aged participants (mean age ~20 years, 28 total participants in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of EPA and DHA as adjuvants to maintenance medication treatments for mild-to-moderate depression, using coconut oil as a placebo.
results_summary: Coconut oil (placebo) showed no significant efficacy in reducing depression symptoms compared to EPA, with no patients in the placebo group responding to treatment.
population_specificity: Mild-to-moderately depressed outpatients (n=81; 61.3% female; mean age 35.1 ± 1.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of coconut oil, palm olein, and virgin olive oil on plasma homocysteine, inflammatory markers, and cardiovascular disease risk in healthy adults.
results_summary: Coconut oil did not significantly affect plasma homocysteine or inflammatory markers compared to the other oils but resulted in higher fasting lipid indexes and postprandial total cholesterol than palm olein and olive oil. However, it uniquely decreased postprandial lipoprotein(a).
population_specificity: 45 healthy adults
effective_dosage: Incorporated at two-thirds of 30% fat calories into high-protein Malaysian diets

study_goal: The researchers were evaluating whether coconut oil, used as a placebo, had any effect on delayed gastric emptying, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and clinical outcomes in ARDS patients compared to ginger extract.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in feeding tolerance between the coconut oil (placebo) and ginger extract groups at 48 hours, though the ginger group showed trends toward reduced pneumonia and better ventilator-free and ICU-free days. Coconut oil's effects were not highlighted as beneficial or detrimental.
population_specificity: 32 ARDS patients dependent on mechanical ventilation and fed via nasogastric tube.

study_goal: The researchers explored whether coconut oil, when used in preterm infant massage therapy, enhances weight gain and other health outcomes.
results_summary: The use of coconut oil in massage therapy was associated with enhanced average weight gain in preterm infants and increased transcutaneous absorption of triglycerides. However, the underlying mechanisms for these effects were not fully explained.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in neonatal intensive care units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coconut oil supplementation influences muscle protein synthesis (MPS) in response to protein ingestion and resistance exercise compared to fish oil.
results_summary: Coconut oil did not significantly affect MPS compared to fish oil, but it altered kinase signaling activity post-exercise and protein ingestion. Both groups showed increased MPS during protein ingestion and exercise, with no supplementation effect.
population_specificity: 20 healthy males

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the effects of fermented and non-fermented aronia extracts on cardiovascular risk factors, with coconut oil included as an ingredient in the snack bars but not as the primary focus.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings related to coconut oil's effects, as the study primarily focused on aronia extracts and their impact on cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Subjects with type 2 diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coconut water, in combination with metformin, could effectively reduce hyperglycemia and enhance antioxidant enzyme activities in diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that combining coconut water with metformin significantly reduced blood glucose levels compared to diabetic controls. Molecular docking revealed strong binding affinities between coconut water compounds (e.g., chlorogenic acid) and metabolic proteins, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (150-220 g) with STZ-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation of coconut oil with breast milk improves growth parameters and body composition in very low birth weight (VLBW) babies.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight gain, head circumference, length, or total body fat percentage between babies receiving breast milk alone and those receiving breast milk with coconut oil. Subscapular skinfold thickness was slightly higher in the coconut oil group, but this did not translate to meaningful clinical differences.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) babies, stratified into appropriate for gestational age (AGA) and small for gestational age (SGA) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method using digital colorimetry and pattern recognition to detect and classify the authenticity of coconut water samples (natural, adulterated, or industrialized).
results_summary: The study demonstrated that digital colorimetry combined with unsupervised pattern recognition techniques effectively classified coconut water samples by authenticity. The method was found to be a quick, low-cost tool for food inspection, aligning with green analytical chemistry principles.
population_specificity: Coconut water samples purchased from street markets and local stores in Bahia, northeastern Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of ultrasound treatment on preserving the quality of tender coconut water during postharvest storage.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment effectively preserved tender coconut water quality by increasing total soluble solids, titratable acid, soluble sugar, and reducing sugar content while decreasing turbidity. It also enhanced taste attributes like astringency and aftertaste without significantly altering volatile organic compounds.
population_specificity: Tender coconut water (liquid endosperm from 6-9-month-old coconuts).
effective_dosage: Ultrasound treatment at 20 kHz, 2400 W for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether young coconut water could reduce blood pressure in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that consuming young coconut water daily for 7 days significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients, while no significant change was observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients aged >35 years with stage I hypertension in Indonesia.
effective_dosage: 150ml once a day in the morning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential adverse effects of excessive maternal coconut water consumption during labor on neonatal outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that excessive maternal coconut water intake during labor led to severe neonatal hyponatremia (serum sodium of 113 mmol/L) and seizures in a term neonate, which resolved after treatment. This highlights the risks of improper fluid and electrolyte management during labor.
population_specificity: Term neonate and the mother during labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of coconut water on hematological indices and lipid profiles in rats with phenylhydrazine-induced anemia.
results_summary: Coconut water administration at 0.5ml/kg reduced LDL, VLDL, and TG levels while increasing HDL levels in rats with induced anemia. It also increased hemoglobin and erythrocyte levels, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for anemia.
population_specificity: Rats with phenylhydrazine-induced anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of pulsed electric field (PEF) processing parameters on the quality and enzyme inactivation of tender coconut water (TCW).
results_summary: PEF treatment significantly increased total phenolic content (23.17%) and antioxidant activity (42.49%) while fully inactivating polyphenol oxidase and partially inactivating peroxidase (60.2%). Sensory acceptability remained unchanged compared to fresh TCW.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on TCW)
effective_dosage: PEF parameters: 8-16 kV/cm, 50-70 μs pulse width, 2000-12,000 pulses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms of probiotic-fermented coconut water in treating acute enteritis in Wenchang chicks, focusing on growth performance, gut microbiota, and metabolic pathways.
results_summary: Probiotic-fermented coconut water improved growth rates, regulated glycerophospholipid metabolism, reshaped gut microbiota, and increased beneficial metabolites like gentamicin C and polymyxin B2, reducing inflammation and promoting recovery from enteritis.
population_specificity: 60 Wenchang chicks with Dextran Sodium Sulfate-induced acute enteritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of coconut water as an adjunct therapy for inducing clinical remission in patients with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Coconut water significantly improved clinical response, remission rates, and fecal calprotectin levels compared to placebo, with no significant adverse events or hyperkalemia reported. The gut microbiome analysis showed beneficial shifts in bacterial taxa correlated with disease activity.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis (SCCAI: 3-9, UCEIS >1), mean age 37.2 years, 54.1% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the thermal inactivation of Listeria innocua in coconut water under isothermal and dynamic conditions to ensure microbiological safety and shelf-life stability.
results_summary: The study found that the Geeraerd model effectively described thermal inactivation of L. innocua in coconut water under isothermal conditions, but models failed under dynamic conditions due to stress acclimation. Acidified TSB was identified as a suitable surrogate medium for studying thermal inactivation in coconut water.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of heat treatment on the physicochemical and antioxidant properties of a beverage formulated from rice flour and coconut water.
results_summary: Heat treatments increased acidity and reducing sugars but decreased pH, total sugar, and antioxidant activity. The mixtures exhibited pseudoplastic fluid behavior, and the physicochemical properties were dependent on the heat treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on beverage formulations rather than human subjects).
effective_dosage: Formulations A (2% RF; 98% CW), B (5% RF; 95% CW), and C (8% RF; 92% CW).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on heat treatment effects, not longitudinal administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and impact of promoting water and coconut water as healthy beverage alternatives in church events to address obesity as a risk factor for noncommunicable diseases.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in the consumption of less healthy beverages, with decreases in water bottles, coconuts, and cups of water used during church events, suggesting that promoting coconut water and water is a feasible and culturally responsive nutrition intervention.
population_specificity: Church attendees in American Samoa, Chuuk, and Kosrae States of the Federated States of Micronesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ACP-Lact® (containing coconut water powder) as a semen cryopreservation extender for goat sperm.
results_summary: ACP-Lact® showed superior progressive motility (36.77%), sperm velocity, viability (95%), and in vivo success (2 births out of 5 inseminated goats) compared to other treatments. It was concluded to be an efficient alternative extender for caprine semen cryopreservation.
population_specificity: Goat semen samples (ejaculate from six goats) and ten female goats for in vivo insemination.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatments included ACP-Lact®, ACP-Lact® 50%, ACP + 2.5% egg yolk, and Tris + 2.5% egg yolk).
study_duration: Not specified (cryopreservation and thawing process described, but no explicit intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bio-preservatives (nisin, natamycin, and polylysine) as alternatives to chemical preservatives for extending the shelf life of tender coconut water (TCW) during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: The study found that polylysine was the most effective bio-preservative for maintaining TCW quality, with pH and overall acceptability being key factors in spoilage. Pasteurized TCW shelf life could be extended up to 20 days using bio-preservatives.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on TCW as a product, not a human population).
study_duration: Up to 20 days of refrigerated storage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of guinea fowl egg yolk concentrations in TRIS and ACP-101c® dilutants on goat semen cryopreservation quality.
results_summary: The study found that guinea fowl egg yolk (GONM) in TRIS and ACP-101c® dilutants preserved sperm kinetics, membrane integrity, mitochondrial potential, and morphology similarly to hen egg yolk (GOGD), with no statistically significant differences.
population_specificity: Anglo Nubian breed goats (semen samples).
effective_dosage: Various concentrations of guinea fowl egg yolk (2.5%, 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%) in TRIS and ACP-101c® dilutants.
study_duration: Cryopreservation followed by assessment after seven days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute and prolonged diuretic effects of coconut water (CW) and its underlying mechanism in a saline-loaded rat model.
results_summary: CW significantly increased urine excretion and urinary sodium and chloride ions in acute and prolonged experiments. It suppressed the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and reduced aquaporin expressions, suggesting CW's potential as a natural diuretic.
population_specificity: Saline-loaded rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypolipidemic and health-beneficial effects of phenolic concentrate from coconut testa and tender coconut water in high-fat-fed mice.
results_summary: Treatment with PHE and TCW concentrates reduced body weight dose-dependently, improved lipid profiles (decreased triglycerides, cholesterol, LDL; increased HDL), and enhanced antioxidant and metabolic markers. The study suggests potential health benefits for managing obesity-related metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: High-fat-fed C57BL/6 mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-intensity ultrasound (US) treatment on the sugar content, enzyme activity, and shelf-life of coconut water.
results_summary: US treatment increased total soluble solids, sugar/acid ratio, and sugar content (sucrose, fructose, glucose) while lowering pH and conductivity. It inhibited sugar metabolism enzymes, particularly acid invertase (AI), by altering its molecular structure and preventing sucrose binding, thereby preserving sugar levels and extending shelf-life.
population_specificity: Tender coconuts (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-cataract effects of coconut water in diabetic rats and cultured lens epithelial cells, and to explore its potential mechanism of action.
results_summary: Coconut water reduced lens opacity and apoptosis in diabetic rats and lens epithelial cells, lowered oxidative stress markers (MDA), and increased antioxidant enzyme activity (SOD, GSH-Px). It mitigated cataract severity and cell damage induced by diabetes.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats and cultured rat lens epithelial cells.
effective_dosage: 5% and 10% coconut water in vitro; in vivo dosage not specified.
study_duration: 20 weeks in vivo, 48 hours in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of coconut water to counteract carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced toxicity in rats, focusing on hematological, lipid, antioxidant, liver, and kidney parameters.
results_summary: Coconut water significantly improved red blood cell counts, antioxidant enzyme levels, and lipid profiles while reducing markers of liver and kidney damage in rats exposed to CCl4. The treatment also lowered harmful biomarkers like malondialdehyde and bilirubin.
population_specificity: Male and female rats exposed to CCl4-induced toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a method for detecting tebuconazole residues in coconut water, kernel, and leaves and assess the dissipation of these residues over time.
results_summary: The study found that tebuconazole residues in coconut water and kernel were below quantifiable limits within three days, while residues in leaves dissipated below quantifiable limits by the 5th day (single dose) or 10th day (double dose). Recovery rates for residue detection ranged from 70% to 114.39%.
population_specificity: Coconut trees (no human subjects studied).
effective_dosage: 5 mL and 10 mL per 100 mL of water per tree.
study_duration: Residues monitored up to 10 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physical and chemical characteristics of coconut water and its effectiveness as a preservative solution for human corneas.
results_summary: Coconut water-based solutions partially maintained corneal transparency and epithelial integrity for the first three days but were less effective than the control (Optisol-GS). Higher osmolality (365 mOsm/L) solutions performed worse, with corneas showing edema, folds, and epithelial loss by the seventh day.
population_specificity: Discarded human corneas from an eye bank.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of UV-C irradiation on oxidative enzymes, essential amino acids, and sensory attributes in coconut water to assess its potential for shelf-life extension.
results_summary: UV-C irradiation at 400 mJ/cm² inactivated PPO and POD enzymes by 94% and 93%, respectively, with no significant changes in essential amino acids. Sensory attributes remained stable up to 200 mJ/cm².
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on coconut water).
effective_dosage: UV-C fluence levels up to 400 mJ/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiretinopathy effects of coconut water on diabetic rats and explore its potential mechanism.
results_summary: Coconut water reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA) and increased antioxidant levels (SOD, GSH-Px), while also decreasing inflammatory markers (IL-6, ICAM-1) in the retina. It improved retinal structure by increasing neuron count and retinal thickness, showing comparable effects to glibenclamide.
population_specificity: Diabetic Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining mild heat with essential oil constituents (EOCs) like carvacrol to inactivate heat-resistant E. coli mutants in coconut water.
results_summary: The combination of mild heat (57.0°C) and carvacrol (200 μl/l) synergistically achieved over 5 log10 reductions of resistant E. coli mutants in coconut water, mitigating their increased resistance. This treatment was also effective against heat-resistant variants of E. coli O157:H7.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (E. coli MG1655 and E. coli O157:H7 ATCC 43888) in buffer and coconut water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a diluent containing coconut water, fructose, and egg yolk in preserving rooster sperm quality when stored at 5°C.
results_summary: The study found that a diluent containing coconut water, egg yolk, and fructose (T2 solution) improved sperm viability and reduced abnormalities after 7 days of storage, though overall sperm motility remained under 40%.
population_specificity: Healthy roosters (10 semen samples from 10 roosters).
effective_dosage: 0.274 ml coconut water, 0.12 ml egg yolk, and 6 µl fructose per 0.2 ml semen sample.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of powdered coconut water solution (ACP 406®) as a culture medium for the survival and development of in vitro goat preantral follicles compared to traditional media (α-MEM).
results_summary: ACP+ (supplemented powdered coconut water) showed equivalent efficacy to MEM+ in maintaining follicle survival and development, with no significant differences in ROS production or follicular/oocyte diameters. Both treatments similarly activated primordial follicles, though ACP+ initially showed better morphological preservation at day 2.
population_specificity: In situ goat preantral follicles (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Culture media contained 100 μg/mL penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin; ACP+ included additional supplements (1.25 mg/mL BSA, 10 μg/mL insulin, 5.5 μg/mL transferrin, 5 ng/mL selenium, 2 mM glutamine, and 2 mM hypoxanthine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of coconut water as a natural diluent for rabbit semen in artificial insemination, focusing on semen quality, conception rate, and litter size.
results_summary: Coconut water significantly affected spermatozoa motility and structural membrane integrity, with the optimal dilution rate at 60% (T4) yielding the highest conception rate, litter size, and productivity index. The least favorable results were observed at 80% dilution (T5).
population_specificity: Crossbred New Zealand White × chinchilla rabbits (10 bucks and 90 does).
effective_dosage: Semen dilutions at 0%, 20%, 40%, 60%, and 80% coconut water, with a control of 50% normal saline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high voltage atmospheric cold plasma (HVACP) technology in inactivating Salmonella enterica in tender coconut water (TCW) and assess its impact on the beverage's physicochemical properties.
results_summary: HVACP treatment inactivated 1.30 log10 of Salmonella enterica in TCW, with citric acid addition enhancing inactivation to 5 log10. Reactive gas species like ozone and hydrogen peroxide were key to microbial inactivation, while minimal physicochemical changes occurred except for significant ascorbic acid loss.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on tender coconut water)
effective_dosage: 400 ppm citric acid added to TCW

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of ultraviolet-C irradiation in inactivating microorganisms (bacteriophages and surrogate bacteria) in highly opaque coconut water.
results_summary: Ultraviolet-C irradiation effectively inactivated bacteriophages and surrogate bacteria in coconut water, achieving over 5-log10 reduction at 40 mJ cm-2. The log reduction kinetics followed log-linear and exponential models with high accuracy (R2 > 0.95).
